content.description: Start sitting on ramp landing with left hand edge and a jug for the right.  A long left reach leads to a fun compression sequence on the arête. Old school line?
content.location: The NW arête of the loaf boulder.

content.description: Climb the left leaning arete leading to the top of Rainshadow.
content.location: Boulder behind dig dug, close to Even Dirtier.
The small pointy boulder behind the Loaf Boulder

content.description: A great climb, whether you are new to bouldering, or are just looking to get your blood flowing.  Start sitting, and head up the obvious large, and sometimes rounded holds to a mellow topout.  This is one of the best v0-v2 climbs at the ranch, and a must do for people working this grade range.
content.location: Far right side on the same face as Dig Dug.

content.description: Just left of the arete climb positive and incut holds up the wall. A little mossy.
Climb the slab face up and to the left. Keep the descent rope of the loaf boulder on your left.
content.location: The problem starts immediately to the right of the descent rope.

content.description: A good v6, with fun moves. It requires consistent body tension for the first several moves before you are established on the face. Great rock, dynamic moves, and certainly worth doing.Crack to the right is considered off for hands and feet, but many argue you can still use it for feet.  The amount one uses the crack (hands, feet,, either, none) affects the grade significantly.

The crux is pulling on and executing the first few moves. Stand start low. Hidden micro crimps make it barely doable. It took me several minutes just to find the starting holds. A few moves up you do a committing dyno to a obvious decent hold. Topping out from there isn't tough but slightly highball.
content.location: If you are facing the Loaf boulder's main wall (with Dig Dug, etc) follow the wall to the right until you go around the corner. Just around the corner is a vertical face. The problem climbs the face without using the arete.

content.description: Start as per Dig Dug, but head left before you climb over the lip at the end of the roof.     Finish on what is often a dirty topout.   It is not clear to me whether this is usually done with the big slopey jug on. Not using any of the holds on the face felt like v4, too.  Mildly tougher than Dig Dug proper.
content.protection: A couple of pads, since it traverses.

content.description: Great problem starting down under the overhang right in the middle of the loaf boulder. sds under roof, climb out to sloper finish. Sometimes wet underneath.
content.location: if facing WMA, look behind you

content.description: Sit start. Climb the pockets to some slopers over the roof.
content.location: the leftmost route on the Loaf Boulder

content.description: Kind of fun albeit contrived traverse, Start seated on the far right side of the boulder and traverse left into dig dug and go up on that climb, the high horizontal jug rail is off, stay low through here for the 7 (v5 called the shortcut if you choose to use it), problem may feel soft in the grade, you can choose to continue traversing into dig dug left(top out at the far left of boulder) to make it a bit more difficult
content.protection: pad or two, stays low most of the traverse is very easy

content.description: Located in the South Idaho Boulders near the confederate cracks
